conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the normal force N between the locking tongue D and the locking groove E when the door is in the self-locking state.
Analyze the forces acting on the latch D.
The spring is compressed by a distance x.
The spring force kx acts horizontally towards the right.
According to Newtonâ€™s third law, there will also be an equal and opposite reaction force that acts on the spring.
The spring force is the one affecting the latch.
There is a frictional force f1 due to the sliding motion along the lower surface of the latch D.
There is a frictional force f2 due to the inclined surface of the latch D.
The normal force N acts perpendicular to the surface of the locking groove E.
The frictional force f1 can be resolved into two components: parallel component f1_parallel = f1 cos(theta) and perpendicular component f1_perp = f1 sin(theta).
The frictional force f2 can be resolved into two components: parallel component f2_parallel = f2 cos(theta) and perpendicular component f2_perp = f2 sin(theta).
The maximum static friction force F_fm is given by F_fm = mu F_N.
Since the door is in the self-locking state, the total frictional force must balance the spring force in the direction perpendicular to the surface.
The net force in the perpendicular direction must balance the spring force: N = kx + f1_perp + f2_perp.
Given that the maximum static friction force is the sum of the components of the frictional forces: N = kx + mu f1 sin(theta) + mu f2 sin(theta).

Since the problem does not provide specific values for f1 and f2, use the fact that the sum of the components of the frictional forces must equal the spring force: N = kx + mu (sin(theta) f1 + sin(theta) f2).
Recognize that in the case of self-locking, the frictional forces f1 and f2 are such that their combined effect equals the spring force in the perpendicular direction: N = kx + mu f.
Assume the frictional force f is the sum of f1 and f2: f = f1 cos(theta) + f2 cos(theta).
Therefore: N = kx + mu (f1 cos(theta) + f2 cos(theta)).
